{"abstract": "In an effort to focus on higher-growth wireless and Internet offerings, Verizon Communications will spin off $2.72 billion in landline businesses in Maine, New Hampshire and Vermont, merging them with FairPoint Communications. {"abstract": "Alltel, the wireless telecommunications company, has stepped up efforts to sell itself to carriers such as AT&T, Verizon Communications and Sprint Nextel, The Wall Street Journal reported. According to The Journal, the wireless operator approached AT&T recently about the possibility of selling itself to the telecoms giant. AT&T is reportedly willing to entertain the possibility, but remains skeptical about a combination because of potential antitrust problems, technology-integration issues and Alltel\u2019s stock-market capitalization, which Friday stood at nearly $22 billion.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2007/03/05/altell-dials-up-carriers-in-hopes-of-a-deal-report-says/", "snippet": "", "lead_paragraph": "Alltel, the wireless telecommunications company, has stepped up efforts to sell itself to carriers such as AT&T, Verizon Communications and Sprint Nextel, The Wall Street Journal reported. {"abstract": "We hate to pile on a company when it\u2019s down, but we couldn\u2019t resist running some numbers on Vonage Holdings, the upstart Internet-based phone company whose initial public offering last year has gone from bad to worse to apocalyptically awful. With the latest downtick in Vonage\u2019s stock, coming after a federal judge ordered it to stop using technology licensed by Verizon, the I.P.O. is by far the worst of 2006, according to Thomson Financial. At $3, the stock has lost more than 82 percent of its value since last May, when it was sold to the public at $17 apiece. The shares are now below the average price paid by Vonage\u2019s pre-I.P.O. investors, a prestigious group of venture and private equity investors including New Enterprise Associates, Meritech Capital Partners, 3i, and Bain Capital. ", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2007/04/11/vonages-dubious-honor-worst-ipo-of-2006/", "snippet": "", "lead_paragraph": "We hate to pile on a company when it\u2019s down, but we couldn\u2019t resist running some numbers on Vonage Holdings, the upstart Internet-based phone company whose initial public offering last year has gone from bad to worse to apocalyptically awful. With the latest downtick in Vonage\u2019s stock, coming after a federal judge ordered it to stop using technology licensed by Verizon, the I.P.O. is by far the worst of 2006, according to Thomson Financial. At $3, the stock has lost more than 82 percent of its value since last May, when it was sold to the public at $17 apiece. {"abstract": " It was just yesterday that DealBook was observing how Vonage Holdings, the Internet phone company, has the dubious honor of being the worst initial public offering, by far, of 2006. Then came word Thursday morning that Vonage\u2019s chief executive, Michael Snyder, has abruptly stepped down and resigned from Vonages\u2019 its board of directors. Thursday\u2019s news release gave no reason for Mr. Snyder\u2019s departure, but the company is clearly in crisis mode. Its stock has lost more than 80 percent of its value since it went public in May, and Vonage is at risk of losing access to an important piece of technology that is the subject of a patent dispute with Verizon. {"abstract": "Rhapsody, the music service owned by Real Networks and Viacom, has been struggling to keep its subscriber base from shrinking. A new joint service with Verizon, an MP3 store, and outreach to social networks may help. But not by much.", "lead_paragraph": "When Rob Williams, the senior vice president for music at Real Networks, came by last week to talk about a bunch of announcements by Rhapsody, the music service jointly owned by Real and Viacom, I have to confess that I felt a bit sorry for him. [{"abstract": "Verizon Communications said Wednesday it would spin off wireline operations in 14 states and merge them with Frontier Communications for $5.3 billion in stock.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2009/05/13/frontier-to-buy-verizon-lines-for-53-billion/", "snippet": "Verizon Communications said Wednesday it would spin off wireline operations in 14 states and merge them with Frontier Communications for $5.3 billion in stock.", "lead_paragraph": "Moving to sharpen its focus on the wireless and broadband businesses, Verizon Communications said Wednesday it would spin off wireline operations spanning 14 states and merge them with Frontier Communications for $5.3 billion in stock. {"abstract": "Verizon is raising the prices for its FiOS bundle of Internet, telephone and television services by $5 to $10 a month, while increasing Internet speeds.", "web_url": "https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/06/22/verizon-raises-fios-prices-but-hardly-mentions-it/", "snippet": "Verizon is raising the prices for its FiOS bundle of Internet, telephone and television services by $5 to $10 a month, while increasing Internet speeds.", "lead_paragraph": " It takes a lot of moxie to raise prices in a deep recession, particularly when you are the newcomer to a hotly competitive market. {"abstract": "Qualcomm hopes to spur sales for its Flo TV video service for cellphones by cutting the price and adding service on the iPhone.", "web_url": "https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/06/24/the-price-flows-down-for-flo-tv/", "snippet": "Qualcomm hopes to spur sales for its Flo TV video service for cellphones by cutting the price and adding service on the iPhone.", "lead_paragraph": "It\u2019s easy to be skeptical about Flo TV, Qualcomm\u2019s effort to bring a mini cable system to your cellphone. The company offers up to 20 channels of TV for $15 a month and up. It is betting that consumers will value it even though more and more video content is available free on demand to any smartphone with streaming video capacity. What\u2019s more, Flo only works on a handful of handsets available from AT&T and Verizon. {"abstract": "Verizon\u2019s cellphones are designed in such a way that you can almost never avoid getting $1.99 charge on the bill for its mobile Web services, even if you immediately cancel the action.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2009/11/12/technology/personaltech/12pogue-email.html", "snippet": "Verizon\u2019s cellphones are designed in such a way that you can almost never avoid getting $1.99 charge on the bill for its mobile Web services, even if you immediately cancel the action.", "lead_paragraph": "Starting next week, Verizon will double the early-termination fee for smartphones. suggesting that the company will market the device.", "web_url": "https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/12/12/google-appears-closer-to-releasing-its-own-phone/", "snippet": "Google has begun internal tests of a phone that employees are calling a \u201cGoogle phone,\u201d suggesting that the company will market the device.", "lead_paragraph": "In recent months, tech blogs have been abuzz with rumors that Google is planning to market its own smartphone based on its Android operating system. The plan would signal a more aggressive effort by Google, which so far has relied on partners to build and market Android phones, to become a force in mobile devices. It could also put Google at odds with those partners, which include Verizon Wireless and Motorola, and it would sharpen its competition with Apple, whose iPhone dominates the high-end smartphone market in the United States. {"abstract": "The market has been stagnant for years, but investors are becoming active again.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2010/06/09/its-just-a-few-deals-but-office-market-is-stirring/", "snippet": "The market has been stagnant for years, but investors are becoming active again.", "lead_paragraph": "In January 2007, not long before the market for commercial buildings peaked, Scott Rechler, the scion of a Long Island real estate family, sold the Reckson Associates Realty Corporation to S. {"abstract": "A customer-service representative from Verizon Wireless said that the company has put a new policy in place to attempt to get more money from customers through data plans. ", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2010/06/17/technology/personaltech/17pogue-email.html", "snippet": "A customer-service representative from Verizon Wireless said that the company has put a new policy in place to attempt to get more money from customers through data plans. ", "lead_paragraph": "As longtime readers know, I think the cellphone industry is one step away from a big-city mugger. Some of their practices are outrageous ripoffs-like how they charge so much for text messages (both the sender and the receiver), even though text messages cost them nothing. Or how the purpose of two-year contract is to sell you an expensive phone cheaply, on the premise that you'll pay it off over the next 24 months -- but once you've paid off the phone, your monthly bill doesn't go down. (Except at T-Mobile.)", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Is Verizon Wireless Making It Harder to Avoid Charges?", "kicker": "From the Desk of David Pogue", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "organizations", "value": "Verizon Communications", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Wireless Communications", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2010-06-17T18:22:56+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Technology", "subsection_name": "Personal Tech", "byline": {"original": "By David Pogue", "person": [{"firstname": "David", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Pogue", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/1e7af33d-5813-57f1-8478-451e59bc99b3", "word_count": 1192, "uri": "nyt://article/1e7af33d-5813-57f1-8478-451e59bc99b3"}

two companies\u00a0 appear to be staking out their ground now, other wireless carriers and media companies are watching and waiting as the Federal Communications Commission looks at ways of regulating {"abstract": "New rules on earnings reporting makes valuing Goldman a bit easier than it once was.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/12/business/12views.html", "snippet": "New rules on earnings reporting makes valuing Goldman a bit easier than it once was.", "lead_paragraph": "Public opprobrium played a hand in Goldman Sachs\u2019s decision to disclose more about its trading and investments for its own account, the first fruits of which emerged in a regulatory filing on Tuesday. But the Wall Street firm\u2019s reorganization of how it reports earnings also serves its own purposes. It makes valuing the firm a bit easier by enabling a better sum-of-the-parts analysis than was previously possible.", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "2", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [{"rank": 0, "subtype": "jumbo", "caption": null, "credit": null, "type": "image", "url": "images/2011/01/12/business/Views/Views-jumbo.jpg", "height": 973, "width": 1024, "subType": "jumbo", "crop_name": "jumbo", "legacy": {}}], "headline": {"main": "Adding Up Parts at Goldman Sachs", "kicker": "Reuters Breakingviews", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Adding Up Parts At Goldman Sachs", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "organizations", "value": "Goldman Sachs Group Inc", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Company Reports", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "iPhone", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Apple Inc", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Verizon Communications Inc", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "AT&T Inc", "rank": 6, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2011-01-12T04:39:03+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By ANTONY CURRIE and ROBERT CYRAN", "person": [{"firstname": "Antony", "middlename": null, "lastname": "CURRIE", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}, {"firstname": "Robert", "middlename": null, "lastname": "CYRAN", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 2}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/beea8146-6670-53c7-8bc2-c00cbab36c2a", "word_count": 724, "uri": "nyt://article/beea8146-6670-53c7-8bc2-c00cbab36c2a"}

{"abstract": "The problem with dropped calls on the iPhone may no longer be blamed on the network now that Apple has signed a deal with Verizon Wireless.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/15/business/15nocera.html", "snippet": "The problem with dropped calls on the iPhone may no longer be blamed on the network now that Apple has signed a deal with Verizon Wireless.", "lead_paragraph": "With this week\u2019s announcement that Verizon Wireless is going to begin selling the iPhone \u0097 something its customers have been panting for ever since AT&T got that first, exclusive iPhone contract four years ago \u0097 it\u2019s time for me to face the music. {"abstract": "To reach the multitude of online services competing for your attention, you must first get through a bottleneck that is not competitive at all: high-speed broadband access.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2012/05/09/business/economy/net-neutrality-and-economic-equality-are-intertwined.html", "snippet": "To reach the multitude of online services competing for your attention, you must first get through a bottleneck that is not competitive at all: high-speed broadband access.", "lead_paragraph": "Imagine a network of private highways that reserved a special lane for Fords to zip through, unencumbered by all the other brands of cars trundling along the clogged, shared lanes. "GOLDMAN BEATS EXPECTATIONS \u00a0|\u00a0 Goldman Sachs may be getting its groove back. The Wall Street firm said on Tuesday that it swung to a profit in the third quarter, reporting net earnings applicable to common shareholders of $1.46 billion, compared with a loss of $428 million in the quarter a year ago. The third-quarter profit amounted to $2.85 a share, beating the $2.12 a share analysts were expecting. Goldman also said it was increasing its dividend to 50 cents from 46 cents. (The conference call to discuss the results is at 9:30 a.m. Dial 1-888-281-7154 to listen in the United States.)", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Goldman Beats Expectations", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2012-10-16T12:52:11+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By William Alden", "person": [{"firstname": "William", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Alden", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/ef19d753-2ed3-5c90-aa3a-ece134db5668", "word_count": 1904, "uri": "nyt://article/ef19d753-2ed3-5c90-aa3a-ece134db5668"}]

{"abstract": "As wireless providers rush to grow through acquisitions, they may end up hurting themselves \u2014 and consumers.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2012/10/23/few-winners-in-heated-cellphone-wars/", "snippet": "As wireless providers rush to grow through acquisitions, they may end up hurting themselves \u2014 and consumers.", "lead_paragraph": "If you are wondering who will be your cellphone provider next year, so are the cellphone companies. Maneuvers by American cellphone providers to acquire one another are threatening to erupt into all-out war. {"abstract": "Amazon.com is quietly building a library of exclusive online content to rival Netflix, the champion of streaming media; cat videos are used to sell things rather than simply distract; and a Japanese television show captures the angst of a major lithium-ion battery manufacturer.", "web_url": "https://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/02/12/the-breakfast-meeting-amazon-challenges-netflix-and-an-advertiser-turns-to-cat-videos/", "snippet": "Amazon.com is quietly building a library of exclusive online content to rival Netflix, the champion of streaming media; cat videos are used to sell things rather than simply distract; and a Japanese television show captures the angst of a major li...", "lead_paragraph": "Amazon.com is slowly building a library of streaming television shows and movies to rival that of Netflix, much to the satisfaction of media companies like Time Warner and CBS, Brian Stelter writes. Amazon will not unveil its own original shows until fall at the earliest, but it has spent hundreds of millions of dollars to win exclusive Web rights on shows for its Amazon Prime streaming service, like \u201cDownton Abbey\u201d from PBS and \u201cFalling Skies\u201d from TNT. Amazon is a long way from matching Netflix in terms of TV and movie selection, but parts of the media business already see the company as Pepsi to Netflix\u2019s Coke. Other companies, including Google, Sony, Intel and a new venture by Redbox and Verizon, are scrambling for a Snapple or Red Bull.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "The Breakfast Meeting: Amazon Challenges Netflix, and an Advertiser Turns to Cat Videos", "kicker": "Media Decoder", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2013-02-12T13:26:52+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Media", "byline": {"original": "By Daniel E. {"abstract": "Vodafone\u2019s stake in Verizon Wireless may be worth $120 billion. If a deal can be reached with Verizon, the big question is what strategic options the British telecommunications would pursue with such a windfall.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2013/03/06/why-vodafone-should-head-for-a-verizon-exit/", "snippet": "Vodafone\u2019s stake in Verizon Wireless may be worth $120 billion. If a deal can be reached with Verizon, the big question is what strategic options the British telecommunications would pursue with such a windfall.", "lead_paragraph": "Vodafone should dash for a United States exit if it\u2019s open. Shares of the British telecommunications company soared on Wednesday on hopes that Verizon Communications could buy it out of their $250 billion-plus joint venture. {"abstract": "In many ways, executive pay is continuing  its merry climb. But shareholders and some company boards have made inroads against the trend.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2013/04/07/business/shareholders-can-slow-the-executive-pay-express.html", "snippet": "In many ways, executive pay is continuing  its merry climb. But shareholders and some company boards have made inroads against the trend.", "lead_paragraph": "RAISES may be hard-won for most American workers these days, but for those fortunate few in the executive suite, the pay increases just keep on coming. Last year, the median chief executive at a United States company with more than $5 billion in revenue received about $14 million, 2.8 percent more than in 2011, according to an annual pay analysis conducted by Equilar. The 2012 increase, though relatively modest, still represents a raise for most of those who inhabit the corner office (and whose companies had filed the data by the end of March). {"abstract": "Amid growing interest in European cable and telecommunications by investors, the British wireless firm Vodafone started acquisition talks with the German cable operator Kabel Deutschland.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2013/06/12/vodafone-pursues-a-german-deal/", "snippet": "Amid growing interest in European cable and telecommunications by investors, the British wireless firm Vodafone started acquisition talks with the German cable operator Kabel Deutschland.", "lead_paragraph": "The British wireless giant Vodafone has approached Kabel Deutschland of Germany over a potential takeover that could be worth more than $10 billion, DealBook\u2019s Mark Scott reports. {"abstract": "Verizon Communications\u2019 move to buy the remainder of Verizon Wireless reflects the extraordinary profit advantage of wireless over landline service.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2013/09/29/business/why-verizon-wanted-it-all.html", "snippet": "Verizon Communications\u2019 move to buy the remainder of Verizon Wireless reflects the extraordinary profit advantage of wireless over landline service.", "lead_paragraph": "IT didn\u2019t come as a complete surprise when Verizon Communications agreed earlier this month to pay $130 billion for the 45 percent of the Verizon Wireless unit that it didn\u2019t already own. What\u2019s startling, though, is the parent company\u2019s dependence on its wireless unit\u2019s operating profit. Without Verizon Wireless, the value of the old Verizon \u2014 the giant telephone company that provides dial-tone service as well as Internet and fiber optic TV to millions of customers \u2014 is vanishingly small.", "print_section": "BU", "print_page": "8", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [{"rank": 0, "subtype": "jumbo", "caption": null, "credit": null, "type": "image", "url": "images/2013/09/29/business/29data-inline/29data-inline-jumbo.jpg", "height": 344, "width": 194, "subType": "jumbo", "crop_name": "jumbo", "legacy": {}}, {"rank": 0, "subtype": "superJumbo", "caption": null, "credit": null, "type": "image", "url": "images/2013/09/29/business/29data-inline/29data-inline-superJumbo.jpg", "height": 344, "width": 194, "subType": "superJumbo", "crop_name": "superJumbo", "legacy": {}}], "headline": {"main": "Why Verizon Wanted It All", "kicker": "Datapoints", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Why Verizon Wanted It All", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "organizations", "value": "Verizon Communications Inc", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Telephones and Telecommunications", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Cellular Telephones", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Wireless Communications", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Vodafone Group Plc", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2013-09-28T18:28:40+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "SundayBusiness", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Anna Bernasek", "person": [{"firstname": "Anna", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Bernasek", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/8e3b12b5-35f3-53b0-b076-816f86cac463", "word_count": 267, "uri": "nyt://article/8e3b12b5-35f3-53b0-b076-816f86cac463"}

"https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/06/05/morning-agenda-sprint-and-t-mobile-near-a-deal-of-their-own/", "snippet": "Sprint and T-Mobile have settled on the terms of a $32 billion deal. | A maverick judge leaves his mark. | Valeant\u2019s opaque business model has been revealed. | Assessing the effects of a multibillion-dollar penalty on BNP\u2019s capital.", "lead_paragraph": "Responding to a wave of consolidation in the telecommunications industry, the nation\u2019s third- and fourth-largest wireless phone operators have agreed to a deal of their own. The operators, Sprint and T-Mobile, which have long contemplated a merger, finally settled on the terms of a $32 billion deal that is likely to be announced this summer, DealBook\u2019s David Gelles and Michael J. de la Merced write. The merger would create a more formidable rival to the two largest wireless phone providers in the United States, Verizon and AT&T. Under the terms of the deal, Sprint, which is majority-owned by Japan\u2019s SoftBank, would acquire T-Mobile for about $40 a share in cash and stock, a 17 percent premium to Wednesday\u2019s price. Accounting for regulatory uncertainty, the early terms of the deal also include a breakup fee of more than $1 billion that Sprint would pay to T-Mobile.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Morning Agenda: Sprint and T-Mobile Near a Deal of Their Own", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2014-06-05T13:20:34+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Sydney Ember", "person": [{"firstname": "Sydney", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Ember", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/6b93d03c-eb06-5cb3-9c55-9e6cd5671cd2", "word_count": 1614, "uri": "nyt://article/6b93d03c-eb06-5cb3-9c55-9e6cd5671cd2"}, {"abstract": "The dust-up comes after the companies agreed that Netflix could pay Verizon to connect directly to its network, creating a faster connection that bypasses the go-between that carries most content through the Internet.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2014/06/06/business/media/verizon-challenges-netflixs-warning-messages-blaming-it-for-slow-streaming-service.html", "snippet": "The dust-up comes after the companies agreed that Netflix could pay Verizon to connect directly to its network, creating a faster connection that bypasses the go-between that carries most content through the Internet.", "lead_paragraph": "Verizon fired back at Netflix on Thursday after it was revealed that Netflix showed its customers an error message blaming Verizon\u2019s network for slowing the streaming of Netflix\u2019s programming. {"abstract": "SugarString ran afoul of the public when The DailyDot reported in October that an editor recruiting journalists was warning them that the site would forbid reporting on \u201cspying and net neutrality.\u201d", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/04/business/media/verizon-shuts-down-sugarstring-technology-site.html", "snippet": "SugarString ran afoul of the public when The DailyDot reported in October that an editor recruiting journalists was warning them that the site would forbid reporting on \u201cspying and net neutrality.\u201d", "lead_paragraph": "As journalism and corporate promotion merge, there have been many interesting experiments. {"abstract": "As government bond yields worldwide get pushed down, corporate debt issuers edging toward junk status are in a sweet spot.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/05/business/dealbook/actaviss-bond-sale-demonstrates-investor-hunger-for-high-yield-debt.html", "snippet": "As government bond yields worldwide get pushed down, corporate debt issuers edging toward junk status are in a sweet spot.", "lead_paragraph": "Actavis is showcasing the value of being barely investment grade. The company, a drug maker that has been making many acquisitions, attracted huge demand this week for $21 billion of bonds it is selling at a mere notch above junk status. They yield less than a bigger and higher-rated debt issue that Verizon did in 2013. Buyers of top-tier debt can\u2019t help but keep looking further downward.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Actavis\u2019s Bond Sale Demonstrates Investor Hunger for High-Yield Debt", "kicker": "Breakingviews", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "organizations", "value": "Actavis PLC", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "ALLERGAN INC", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Stocks and Bonds", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2015-03-04T17:12:41+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "DealBook", "byline": {"original": "By Robert Cyran", "person": [{"firstname": "Robert", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Cyran", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/f1bedf69-a34c-5e6e-a43a-91ce49090c2a", "word_count": 374, "uri": "nyt://article/f1bedf69-a34c-5e6e-a43a-91ce49090c2a"}

{"abstract": "The unions, representing employees in the East, say they have made little progress with management in the eight months since their contracts expired.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/12/business/two-unions-set-strike-deadline-for-36000-verizon-workers.html", "snippet": "The unions, representing employees in the East, say they have made little progress with management in the eight months since their contracts expired.", "lead_paragraph": "Two unions representing roughly 36,000 Verizon workers in the eastern United States have set a strike deadline of Wednesday morning, saying they have made little progress with management in the more than eight months since their most recent contracts expired. {"abstract": "Shareholders should be willing to sell near an offer price rather than wait to see a merger close", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/08/business/dealbook/investors-remorse-follows-buyers-remorse-as-big-deals-fall-apart.html", "snippet": "Shareholders should be willing to sell near an offer price rather than wait to see a merger close", "lead_paragraph": "A spate of corporate deal remorse has left investors regretful, too. Abbott Laboratories on Wednesday cited \u201cmaterial adverse events\u201d in a legal bid to end its $5.8 billion takeover of the medical test maker Alere. Similar tensions have arisen in mergers involving Yahoo, Williams and Cigna. {"abstract": "A security researcher says hackers are offering records of more than 1 billion users, but as with the company\u2019s stock, the price is dropping.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/15/technology/hacked-yahoo-data-for-sale-dark-web.html", "snippet": "A security researcher says hackers are offering records of more than 1 billion users, but as with the company\u2019s stock, the price is dropping.", "lead_paragraph": "SAN FRANCISCO \u2014 Some time around August 2013, hackers penetrated the email system of Yahoo, one of the world\u2019s largest and oldest providers of free email services.
